citeinfo.title: Predicted Change in Irregularly Flooded Marshes from 2004 to 2100 for Southern Jefferson County, Texas

descript.abstract: This file was created using the Land Change Modeler in the Taiga edition of the Idrisi GIS and Image Processing software from the SLAMM landcover maps created for southern Jefferson County, Texas. The file represents the gains, losses, and persistence for the irregularly flooded marsh category between the 2004 landcover map of actual conditions and the predicted 2100 landcover map of potential future condition, which was derived from the SLAMM model. The gains category represents all new areas of the category by 2100, while losses represent areas of loss of the category by 2100 from its initial locations in 2004. The persistence category represents areas where the category was predicted to remain by 2100.
descript.purpose: This file was created for The Nature Conservancy's Sea Level Rise Project for the northern Gulf of Mexico. The map represents the gain, losses, and persistence for a specific landcover category between two landcover maps representing two points in time. The landcover maps used for the study area were derived from Sea Level Rise Affecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) using the 1m of sea-level rise by 2100 scenario and show how marshes are predicted to migrate inland due to rises in sea level by 2100.

idinfo.useconst: The user accepts all responsibility for use of these data.
